A case study in restaurant success, Phnom Penh serves food that has drawn daily lineups after 25 years.ORDER THE: chicken wings (No. 78), which are deep-fried, tossed with salt and a touch of sugar, and dunked in a peppery lime dipping sauce; the marinated butter beef (No. 71), a carpaccio wonder covered in heaps of cilantro, garlic, soy sauce, and vinegar; and the stew-like filet beef luc lac with a fried egg and rice (No. 35).THE VIBE IS: noisy and crowded but efficient and friendly.PRACTICAL STUFF: Open every day: Monday to Thursday, from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m., and Friday to Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. No reservations needed, but come early for lunch to avoid the lines.—Lindsay AndersonGrant HarderGrant HarderWE ALSO LOVEMaenamReinvented Thai cuisine (and cocktails) in Kitsilano   The Ramen ButcherUmami heaven and house-made noodles in ChinatownHarooHome-style Korean on Richmond’s famous Food Street Explore City GuidesAtlantaAustinBostonCharlestonChicagoCopenhagenLas VegasLondonLos AngelesMexico CityMiamiMontrealNew OrleansNew YorkParisPhiladelphiaPortlandSan FranciscoSeattleTokyoTorontoVancouverWashington, D.C.GET THE MAGAZINEBA LogoBon appetitSUBSCRIBESign up for Updates on the Bon AppétitCity GuidesSign UpWill be used in accordance with our user agreement and privacy policyBA LogoBon appetitSubscription FAQsMastheadNewsletter SignupAccessibility HelpRSS FeedsSite MapCondé Nast StoreCareersBon Appétit Media KitDo Not Sell My Personal InformationCondé NastFood Innovation Group: Bon Appétit and Epicurious© 2022 Condé Nast.
